Certainly, there are many cities around the world that have successfully implemented green roofs and buildings. Here are a few examples:

1. Chicago, Illinois: Chicago has been a pioneer in green roofs, with over 500 green roofs covering more than 7 million square feet. The city's green roof program started in 2003 and has been highly successful in reducing urban heat island effect, managing stormwater runoff, and improving air quality.

2. Copenhagen, Denmark: The Danish capital has set a goal to become carbon neutral by 2025, and green roofs and buildings are a key component of its sustainable urban plan. The city has a target of installing green roofs on 20% of all flat roofs by 2025.

3. Toronto, Canada: Toronto has been a leader in promoting green roofs for over a decade, with a green roof bylaw that requires new buildings to include a green roof. The city has over 240 green roofs covering approximately 1.7 million square feet.

4. Singapore: The city-state of Singapore is known for its highly innovative and sustainable urban planning. It has incorporated green roofs and walls into its cityscape as part of its efforts to improve the livability of the city.

5. Hamburg, Germany: Hamburg has taken a holistic approach to sustainability, including green roofs and buildings as part of its comprehensive urban plan. It has set a target of covering 100% of all new public buildings with green roofs.

These are just a few examples of cities successfully implementing green roofs and buildings, and there are many more around the world that are taking steps toward sustainable development.
